form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Casey (for himself, Ms. Baldwin, Mr. Blumenthal, Mr. Booker, Mr. Cardin, Ms. Duckworth, Mr. Durbin, Mrs. Feinstein, Mr. Fetterman, Mrs. Gillibrand, Ms. Hirono, Ms. Klobuchar, Mr. Markey, Mr. Menendez, Mr. Murphy, Mr. Padilla, Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Shaheen, Mr. Van Hollen, Ms. Warren, Mr. Welch, Mr. Whitehouse, Mr. Wyden, Mr. Luján, and Mr. Merkley) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To prevent a person who has been convicted of a misdemeanor hate crime, or received an enhanced sentence for a misdemeanor because of hate or bias in its commission, from obtaining a firearm.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Disarm Hate Act.

section.header: Prevention of person who has been convicted of a misdemeanor hate crime, or received an enhanced sentence for a misdemeanor because of hate or bias in its commission, from obtaining a firearm

subsection.text: Section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The term convicted in any court of a misdemeanor hate crime—

subparagraph.text: means being convicted by a court of an offense that—

clause.text: is a misdemeanor under Federal, State, or Tribal law;

has, as an element, that the conduct of the offender was motivated by hate or bias because of the actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity (as defined in section 249), or disability of any person; and
involves the use or attempted use of physical force, the threatened use of a deadly weapon, or other credible threat to the physical safety of any person; and
a conviction of an offense described in subparagraph (A), unless—

item.text: was represented by counsel in the case; or
knowingly and intelligently waived the right to counsel in the case; and

subclause.text: in the case of a prosecution for an offense described in subparagraph (A) for which a person was entitled to a jury trial in the jurisdiction in which the case was tried—

item.text: the case was tried by a jury; or
the person knowingly and intelligently waived the right to have the case tried by a jury, by guilty plea or otherwise; or

clause.text: a conviction of an offense described in subparagraph (A) if—

item.text: has been expunged or set aside; or
is an offense for which the person has been pardoned or has had civil rights restored (if the law of the applicable jurisdiction provides for the loss of civil rights under such an offense); and

subclause.text: the pardon, expungement, or restoration of civil rights does not expressly provide that the person may not ship, transport, possess, or receive firearms.

paragraph.text: The term received from any court an enhanced hate crime misdemeanor sentence—

subparagraph.text: means a court has imposed a sentence for a misdemeanor under Federal, State, or Tribal law—

clause.text: that involves the use or attempted use of physical force, the threatened use of a deadly weapon, or other credible threat to the physical safety of any person; and
based, in whole or in part, on a judicial finding that the conduct of the offender was motivated, in whole or in part, by hate or bias for any reason referred to in paragraph (38)(A)(ii); and
the imposition of a sentence described in subparagraph (A), unless—

item.text: was represented by counsel in the case; or
knowingly and intelligently waived the right to counsel in the case; and

subclause.text: if the sentence described in subparagraph (A) was imposed in a prosecution for an offense for which a person was entitled to a jury trial in the jurisdiction in which the case was tried—

item.text: the case was tried by a jury; or
the person knowingly and intelligently waived the right to have the case tried by a jury, by guilty plea or otherwise; or

clause.text: the imposition of a sentence described in subparagraph (A) if—

item.text: the conviction of the offense for which the sentence was imposed has been expunged or set aside; or

the offense for which the sentence was imposed is an offense for which the person has been pardoned or has had civil rights restored (if the law of the applicable jurisdiction provides for the loss of civil rights under such an offense); and

subclause.text: the pardon, expungement, or restoration of civil rights does not expressly provide that the person may not ship, transport, possess, or receive firearms.

subsection.header: Prohibition on sale or other disposition of firearm
subsection.text: Section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (10), by striking or at the end;
by inserting after paragraph (10) the following:
has been convicted in any court of a misdemeanor hate crime, or has received from any court an enhanced hate crime misdemeanor sentence; or
in paragraph (12), as so redesignated, by striking (10) and inserting (11).

subsection.header: Prohibition on possession, shipment, or transport of firearm
subsection.text: Section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (8), by striking or at the end;
in paragraph (9), by striking the comma and inserting ; or; and
by inserting after paragraph (9) the following:
who has been convicted in any court of a misdemeanor hate crime, or has received from any court an enhanced hate crime misdemeanor sentence,
